text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

--- Denmark's tobacco industry spent about 22 million crowns on advertising in newspapers and magazines last year to keep earnings up in spite of anti smoking campaigns and a decreasing number of smokers in the western world.

--- Police do not take shoplifting seriously, a Danish retail organisation says, urging all shops to report every shoplifting incident to the police . According to Danish Trade and Service the police give higher priority to other tasks, leading small shops especially to not beother reporting shoplifting as they think it is too much trouble.

--- Health minister Yvonne Herloev Andersen is to go to the United Arab Emirates on an official visit in December with a group of representatives from Danish medical firms and suppliers of medical equipment for hospitals and institutions for elderly and handicapped people. The delegation is among others to participate in the largest health trade exhibition in the Middle East, "Arab Health '96".

--- The power struggle in the Kremlin has made Danish exporters watch political developments in Russia very closely. So far it does not seem that the political problems in Russian have affected Danish companies' activities in Russia, but transport companies fear that unstable conditions could mean a great loss for Danish exports to Russia which were almost four billion crowns last year.

--- Large increases in bond and share prices since new year has given banks trading profits estimated at about 4-9 billion crowns this year. Securities trading earned the banks 10 billion crowns in 1995.
